Physics: The Post-Critical Period (Opus postumum)
4. Physics: The Post-Critical Period (Opus postumum)

Kant’s interest in physics continued after the publication of
the Metaphysical Foundations, in fact, until the very end of
his productive years. Though Kant never completed a manuscript that
could be put forward as a publication, the various notes, sketches,
and drafts on topics in physics that he was working on intensively
during this time (especially after 1796) were gathered together over a
century after his death and published as his so-called Opus
postumum. It is a highly fragmentary work where Kant’s
thoughts remained in flux through the final parts, written ca. 1802.
Accordingly, scholarship has sought to recover the evolution,
background and import of his reflections, rather than some stable
doctrine, which it mostly lacks. Below we touch on his reason for
writing the Opus at all; two major themes relevant to
philosophy of science; and some implications for his natural
philosophy.

Why did Kant around 1796 begin to draft a new work? Most interpreters
agree that he thought the Opus aimed to fill a
‘gap’ of sorts. In letters from 1798, he speaks
cryptically about there being a ‘gap’ in his Critical
philosophy. Many have concluded the Opus aimed to fill
this gap, and so they turned their attention to identifying
it. Some claimed it was a gap in Kant’s theory of matter above
(in particular, his accounts of mass and density); others saw it
between his constitutive and regulative approaches to metaphysical
foundations for science; yet others have said it was a lacuna in his
schematism of the categories. Lately, Howard (2023) has argued that it
was a missing part in the ‘system of philosophy’ as a
whole (hiatus in systemato, 21:476). He reads that as the
need to mediate—by devising a bridge doctrine—between
Kant’s metaphysical foundations of natural science and
‘physics as a system.’

This reading elucidates two obscure parts in the Opus. One is
Kant’s repeated attempts to articulate a
‘transition.’ In the picture that Howard sketches, the
transition would be the very mediating doctrine above: between a
theory in metaphysics and a body of empirical knowledge. The other is
Kant’s repeated attempts there to define physics such
that he can defensibly say it counts as systematic science. For
instance: “Physics is systematic investigation of nature through
empirically given forces of matter insofar as they are connected to
each other in a system” (22:298). Note just how broad his
definition is—it makes the various ‘forces’
theorized by early-modern chemistry, heat science, botany and animal
physiology count as part of physics qua organized doctrine.

A central theme in the Opus is Kant’s attempt to give
an a priori proof that a certain entity must exist. He calls it the
‘ether,’ and also ‘caloric.’ He thought of it
as a sort of universal substrate—a fluid-like medium that fills
all of physical space, supports ‘moving forces,’ and
carries their actions from one place to another (much like pressure
applied at a point in an incompressible fluid travels across it to
other locations). Kant saw it as his task to give a
‘deduction’ of this medium, viz. a species of
non-empirical evidence that it exists. Generally interpreters take his
Ätherbeweis to be an actual deductive argument, which
they have tried to reconstruct (see, e.g., Förster 2000 and Hall
2006).

Another major theme there is Kant’s quest for an
‘elementary system of the moving forces’ of nature. He
means a methodic, or well-ordered, derivation of the
‘specific’ properties of matter. They are specific in that
none counts as general, or common to all matter; but none is too
particular or transient either. Rather, each is a feature of some
broad class of material behavior. Among the properties Kant ponders at
this juncture are ‘heat,’ ’weight,’
’elasticity,’ ’solidity,’ and the like. He
takes these properties to be associated with ‘moving
forces’: they result from some force being exerted (e.g.,
gravity induces weight) or they cause some force of motion (e.g.
elastic rebound pushes back the body that compressed an elastic
material). So, an elementary system of properties will be ipso facto a
system of forces as well. In regard to it, Kant sought a rational
heuristic: a recipe or criterion for a taxonomic account (of
these broadly-specific properties) that is a priori, viz. inferable
before they are empirically discovered.

Lastly, what did Kant think his ether—and, alternatively, his
‘elementary’ system—would achieve? Here too,
scholarship is somewhat divided. Older accounts thought the
‘ether, or caloric’ was Kant’s basis for the bridge
doctrine, or transition, between metaphysics and empirical physics.
More recently, Howard (2023) has argued for a different line. Namely,
that Kant saw the ether deduction (and the taxonomy of
‘elementary’ forces) as the basis for an account of what
makes empirical physics a systematic body of knowledge—or would
make it so in the long run, if properly pursued.

The Opus postumum has long been a topic of interest
especially insofar as it offers the hope of clarification and
development of central issues in Kant’s Critical philosophy.
Much scholarship on it was in German (Adickes 1920, Hoppe 1969,
Tuschling 1971, Blasche 1991, and Emundts 2004). Then it received
increased attention in English, with discussions by Friedman (1992,
chapter 5), Förster (2000), Edwards (2000), Guyer (2001), and
Hall (2006, 2009). Recent views on the Opus and its reception
are presented in Basile (2013) and Basile & Lissy (2022). Howard
(2023) is an overview of its key issues, and a novel reading of the
natural-philosophical issues Kant tackled there.
